subject: Add Host selector yaml configuration
commitMessage:
Add Host selector yaml configuration

Host selector interface is used to keep the position
of the host selector HW switch as a property.
This host selector position value decides which host
or bmc is currently selected in a multihost bmc system
so that the power and reset button events are
routed to the currently selected host or bmc's power control events.

Tested:
  It's tested in Facebook multi-host Yosemitev2 system,
including in the Front panel with its selector button.

Signed-off-by: Manikandan Elumalai <manikandan.hcl.ers.epl@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I18b4bd779c467d7ddc5045c5380d93c1b8a73b74

Patch Set 28: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged by Patrick Williams

I have some confusion on this being classified as a "button".  It seems like your implementation has a "position up" and "position down" button which you are turning into a Position property (or maybe you just have "position up").

At a hardware level you could implement a position selector in (at least) 3 ways:
    - A position up button with an optional position down.
    - A rotary dial.
    - A slider with stops from position 0 to N.

I suspect the consumer of this "button" should not care which of the 3 hardware implementations the design has, but this interface design you've chosen implies the first option.  Please think about how all 3 hardware designs could be modeled from a software perspective and modify this interface to cover.

It is quite likely that the signals will need to change, maybe to just a single signal like "position changed" but then I don't know why we need another signal beyond the PropertyChanged signal on Position.

Selector button also same as power and reset button which has pressed & released signal . 

Software logic in the selector button moves only up position and rolls over again to host1 after reached to last host.

we have Rotary Switch in Facebook multi-host system to handle position up & down detection additional to the selector button in OCP debug card[1]. 

We have Facebook specific process[2] runs parallel to the phosphor-buttons and keeps current host state in the "Position" property exposed by phosphor-buttons. 

The user can do power control either from Rotary switch or from selector button OCP debug card.


[1] phosphor-buttons
[2] https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/meta-facebook/+/39349
Ack

> Selector button also same as power and reset button which has pressed & released signal . 

> Software logic in the selector button moves only up position and rolls over again to host1 after reached to last host.

These are hardware implementation details that I don't think are interesting for dbus interfaces.  *Your* piece of hardware has a single selector button that rolls over, but someone else could make a rotary dial implementation.  We need to abstract the hardware here.
I think you need to have a property to hold the number of positions, right?

This property holds the current position not total position . The total number of host pass from machine layer for platforms.

Are you suggesting to add one more property to hold the total number of position as readable property.
Ack
Yes, suggest another property with max number of positions.
Ack

This is a particular implementation of your button and should not be documented in the interface.

I would suggest 0-based position numbers for a selector.
Ack
Ack

Please fix the line wrap of your commit message.  < 80 char at least, but prefer 72.

See https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/#wrap-72
What does simPress do w.r.t. signals below?  This method doesn't seem relevant to what you're defining with signals.

phosphor-buttons takes two kind of signal from below hardware to update the position,
 
  1. OCP Debug card single GPIO button press(Pressed/Released signal)
  2. Rotary switch(up/down)

In Facebook Yosemitev2 platform , user can change host position by below scenario,

  * Using OCP debug card with simple press single GPIO button to increment position(No decrement/down)
  * Using Rotary/knob switch to change up/down signal to update the position.

Are we intending to be able to disable?  What does "disabled" mean?

I see other buttons have this property but the ID button doesn't.  I'm not sure why you would or would not want it.
Ack
size_t please.
Ack
size_t please
Ack
Why do we have pressed / released and up / down?

phosphor-buttons takes two kind of signal from below hardware to update position,
 
  1. OCP Debug card single GPIO button press(Pressed/Released signal)
  2. Rotary switch(up/down signal)

It seems like you're trying to model your hardware in this object rather than creating an appropriate abstraction for software to consume.  "Pressed" and "Released" on a selector doesn't have any meaning, and no software should consume it.

It sounds like in your OCP debug card implementation there is a single button press which only increases the selector (and then wraps around at max).  In that case, the button press at a hardware level would cause the Up signal.

To be honest, I'm not even convinced we need these signals on the Selector because we already have PropertyChanged signals that will be emitted for Position, but if you want to keep them here for consistency with other buttons, that is up to you.  I would suggest you think through how they would be used by a consuming client and if you can think of any use for them over monitoring the Position property directly.

Agreed with you on the above point. In that case we don't need Selector.yaml as it is our platform specific and "Pressed" and "Released" on a selector doesn't have any meaning as it not going to use it. 

But we need to add the "Position" and "Maximum Position" property into D-Bus . Can we add this two property in one of the other buttons(Power, Reset, ID, so that we remove this Selector.yaml.
(See below comment).  Also not sure what "Press" means in this context.

I still don't understand the usage of these signals.  How is a selector "pressed" or "released"?  If implemented as a rotary dial physically then these don't make any sense.

Why is the signal off Position not sufficient?

I think a  reference to the design doc would be helpful either here or in the commit message, though now that would just have to point at a gerrit commit.  Maybe if this merges firsts you could add a comment to it here in later commit after the design doc merges.

Check word wrapping.

Is something like this better wording:

"The current position of the selector.  Position N selects Host Instance N, while Position 0 selects the BMC."
Ack

Add to this property:

  flags:
    - readonly


You should be able to find exmaples in other interfaces.
Ack
Why N+1 and not 0?  What is "N" in this context?
Yes changed it. Setting position 0 for bmc can be better option, keeping in mind that in this way it does not change naming conventions used for single host systems.
